subject: RE: [junit] How do I implement a test case for a thrown exception ?

messageBody:
This should be added to the FAQ on www.junit.org.

--- dror2@... wrote:
> Thus we can summarise the pattern for Exception testing:
>
> try {
> //tested code starts here.
> ...
>
> fail( "should have thrown exception TestedException" )
> } catch ( TestedException ) { return }
> } catch ( Exception e ) { fail( "thrown wrong exception: "+e ); }
>
>
> I have written an extension to TestCase, that gives the above
> behaviour.
> Instead of the try/catch blocks, you call a single method at the
> beginning
> of the test
> shouldThrow( TestedException.class );
> and the TestCase does the rest.
>
> Anyone, let me know if it is of any interest.
>
> (the reason I'm not sure its useful, is what Kent has written about
> the
> simplicity of the framework: I'm not sure the complexity of adding
> an
> extra method to TestCase justify the removal of the above 4-line
> patten)
>
>
>
>
>
> "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@...>
> 14/07/2001 22:17
> Please respond to junit
>
>
> To: "'junit@yahoogroups.com'" <junit@yahoogroups.com>
> cc:
> Subject: RE: [junit] How do I implement a test case
> for a thrown exception ?
>
>
> No. The fail() immediately following isPartnerAssigned() would
> fail the
> test if the exception was not thrown. If any other exception is
> thrown,
> the
> catch{} for those would fail the test. You could add another catch
> for
> java.lang.Exception in case you think that might be thrown, but it
> doesn't
> sound like the contract for your method.
>
> -Jason
>
> > You still need a fail after the try/catch to account for the
> > possibility that no exception was thrown.
> >
> > --- Jason Rogers <jason.rogers@...> wrote:
> > > If you want to eliminate the boolean, use your first
> > example and do
> > > the
> > > assert in the catch block.
> > >
> > > public void test_00_isPartnerAssigned() {
> > >
> > > try {
> > >
> > instancePartnerHierarchyWorker.isPartnerAssigned(null);
> > > fail("IllegalArgumentException should be
> thrown.");
> > >
> > > } catch (IllegalArgumentException iae) {
> > >
> > > assert(true);
> > >
> > > } catch (PartnerNotFoundException pnfe){
> > >
> > > fail("PartnerNotFoundException should not
> > be thrown.");
> > >
> > > } catch (PersistenceException pe){
> > >
> > > fail("PersistenceException should not be
> thrown.");
> > > }
> > > }
> > >
> > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > From: Mike Duffy [mailto:mduffy_lists@...]
> > > > Sent: Friday, July 13, 2001 11:24 PM
> > > > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > > Subject: Re: [junit] How do I implement a test case
> for a
> > > thrown
> > > > exception?
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Also, this is better than the structure I originally
> > > > proposed because
> > > > it eliminates the need for a boolean flag.
> > > >
> > > > --- Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@...>
> wrote:
> > > > > > The Junit.org site has an FAQ section
> > > > > > (http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm)
> with
> > > > the following
> > > > > > question: How do I implement a test case for a
> thrown
> > > > exception?
> > > > > >
> > > > > > The answer they give is not completely
> > correct because it
> > > does
> > > > > not
> > > > > > account for the possiblility that another
> > exception could
> > > be
> > > > > thrown.
> > > > >
> > > > > I think they assume that your method only throws
> one
> > > > exception. If
> > > > > your method throws more exceptions, you can use:
> > > > >
> > > > > // Test IllegalArgumentException is thrown when
> > > > partnerID is null.
> > > > > public void test_00_isPartnerAssigned() {
> > > > > try {
> > > > > boolean assignedStatus =
> > > > >
> > > instancePartnerHierarchyWorker.isPartnerAssigned(null);
> > > > > } catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
> > > > > return;
> > > > > } catch (Exception e) {
> > > > > fail("IllegalArgumentException should have
> been
> > > thrown.");
> > > > > }
> > > > > fail("IllegalArgumentException should have been
> > > thrown.");
> > > > > }
> > > > >
> > > > > -Vladimir
